A STORY OF CHRISTMAS EVE. Strange that the termagant winds should scold The Christmas Eve so bitterly! But Wife, and Harry the four-year-old, Big Charley, Nimblewits, and I, Blithe as the wind was bitter, drew More frontward of the mighty fire, Where wise Newfoundland Fan foreknew The heaven that Christian dogs desireâ Stretched o'er the rug, serene and grave, Huge nose on heavy paws reclined, With never a drowning boy to save, And warmth of body and peace of mind. And, as our happy circle sat, The fire well capp'd the company: In grave debate or careless chat, A right good fellow, mingled he: He seemed as one of us to sit, And talked of things above, below, With flames more winsome than our wit, And coals that burned like love aglow. While thus our rippling discourse rolled Smooth down the channel of the night, We spoke of Time: thereat, one told A parable of the Seasons' flight. âTime was a Shepherd with four sheep. In a certain Field he long abode. He stood by the bars, and his flock bade leap One at a time to the Common Road. âAnd first there leapt, like bird on wing, A lissome Lamb that played in the air. I heard the Shepherd call him Spring: Oh, large-eyed, fresh and snowy fair âHe skipped the flowering Highway fast, Hurried the hedgerows green and white, Set maids and men a-yearning, passed The Bend, and gamboll'd out of sight. âAnd next marched forth a matron Ewe (While Time took down a bar for her), Udder'd so large 'twas much ado E'en then to clear the barrier. âFull softly shone her silken fleece What stately time she paced along: Each heartsome hoof-stroke wrought increase Of sunlight, substance, seedling, song, âIn flower, in fruit, in field, in bird, Till the great globe, rich fleck'd and pied, Like some large peach half pinkly furred, Turned to the sun a glowing side âAnd hung in the heavenly orchard, bright, None-such, complete. Then, while the Ewe Slow passed the Bend, a blur of light, The Shepherd's face in sadness grew: ââSummer!â he said, as one would say A sigh in syllables. So, in haste (For shame of Summer's long delay, Yet gazing still what way she paced), âHe summoned Autumn, slanting down The second bar. Thereover strode A Wether, fleeced in burning brown, And largely loitered down the Road. âFar as the farmers sight his shape Majestic moving o'er the way, All cry To harvest, crush the grape, And haul the corn and house the hay, âTill presently, no man can say, (So brown the woods that line that end) If yet the brown-fleeced Wether may, Or not, have passed beyond the Bend. âNow turn I towards the Shepherd: lo, An aged Ram, flapp'd, gnarly-horn'd, With bones that crackle o'er the snow, Rheum'd, wind-gall'd, rag-fleec'd, burr'd and thorn'd âTime takes the third bar off for him, He totters down the windy lane. 'Tis Winter, still: the Bend lies dim. O Lamb, would thou wouldst leap again!â Those seasons out, we talked of these: And I (with inward purpose sly To shield my purse from Christmas trees And stockings and wild robbery When Hal and Nimblewits invade My cash in Santa Claus's name) In full the hard, hard times surveyed; Denounced all waste as crime and shame; Hinted that âwasteâ might be a term Including skates, velocipedes, Kites, marbles, soldiers, towers infirm, Bows, arrows, cannon, Indian reeds, Cap-pistols, drums, mechanic toys, And all th' infernal host of horns Whereby to strenuous hells of noise Are turned the blessed Christmas morns; Thus, rousedâthose horns!âto sacred rage, I rose, forefinger high in air, When Harry cried (some war to wage), âPapa, is hard times ev'ywhere? âMaybe in Santa Claus's land It isn't hard times none at all!â Now, blessed Vision! to my hand Most pat, a marvel strange did fall. Scarce had my Harry ceased, when âLook!â He cried, leapt up in wild alarm, Ran to my Comrade, shelter took Beneath the startled mother's arm. And so was still: what time we saw A foot hang down the fireplace! Then, With painful scrambling scratched and raw, Two hands that seemed like hands of men Eased down two legs and a body through The blazing fire, and forth there came Before our wide and wondering view A figure shrinking half with shame, And half with weakness. âSir,â I said, âBut with a mien of dignity The seedy stranger raised his head: âMy friends, I'm Santa Claus,â said he. But oh, how changed! That rotund face The new moon rivall'd, pale and thin; Where once was cheek, now empty space; Whate'er stood out, did now stand in. His piteous legs scarce propped him up: His arms mere sickles seemed to be: But most o'erflowed our sorrow's cup When that we sawâor did not seeâ His belly: we remembered how It shook like a bowl of jelly fine: An earthquake could not shake it now; He had no bellyânot a sign. âYes, yes, old friends, you well may stare: I have seen better days,â he said: âBut now, with shrinkage, loss and care, Your Santa Claus scarce owns his head. âWe've had such hard, hard times this year For goblins! Never knew the like. All Elfland's mortgaged! And we fear The gnomes are just about to strike. âI once was rich, and round, and hale. The whole world called me jolly brick; But listen to a piteous tale. Young Harry,âSanta Claus is sick! â'Twas thus: a smooth-tongued railroad man Comes to my house and talks to me: âI've got,â says he, âa little plan That suits this nineteenth century. ââInstead of driving, as you do, Six reindeer slow from house to house, Let's build a Grand Trunk Railway through From here to earth's last terminus. ââWe'll touch at every chimney-top (An Elevated Track, of course), Then, as we whisk you by, you'll drop Each package down: just think, the force ââYou'll save, the time!âBesides, we'll make Our millions: look you, soon we will Compete for freightsâand then we'll take Dame Fortune's bales of good and ill ââ(Why, she's the biggest shipper, sir, That e'er did business in this world!): Then Death, that ceaseless Traveller, Shall on his rounds by us be whirled. ââWhen ghosts return to walk with men, We'll bring 'em cheap by steam, and fast: We'll run a Branch to heaven! and then We'll riot, man; for then, at last ââWe'll make with heaven a contract fair To call, each hour, from town to town, And carry the dead folks' souls up there, And bring the unborn babies down!â âThe plan seemed fair: I gave him cash, Nay, every penny I could raise. My wife e'er cried, â'Tis rash, 'tis rash:â How could I know the stock-thief's ways? âBut soon I learned full well, poor fool! My woes began, that wretched day. The President plied me like a tool. In lawyer's fees, and rights of way, âInjunctions, leases, charters, I Was meshed as in a mighty maze. The stock ran low, the talk ran high: Then quickly flamed the final blaze. âWith never an inch of trackâ'tis true! The debts were large ... the oft-told tale. The President rolled in splendor new âHe bought my silver at the sale. âYes, sold me out: we've moved away. I've had to give up everything. My reindeer, even, whom I ... pray, Excuse meâ ... here, o'er-sorrowing, Poor Santa Claus burst into tears, Then calmed again: âmy reindeer fleet, I gave them up: on foot, my dears, I now must plod through snow and sleet. âRetrenchment rules in Elfland, now; Yes, every luxury is cut off. âWhich, by the way, reminds me how I caught this dreadful hacking cough: âI cut off the tail of my Ulster furred To make young Kris a coat of state. That very night the storm occurred! Thus we become the sport of Fate. âFor I was out till after one, Surveying chimney-tops and roofs, And planning how it could be done Without my reindeers' bouncing hoofs. ââMy dear,â says Mrs. Claus, that night (A most superior woman she!) âIt never, never can be right That you, deep-sunk in poverty, ââThis year should leave your poor old bed, And trot about, bent down with toys, (There's Kris a-crying now for bread!) To give to other people's boys. ââSince you've been out, the news arrives The Elfs' Insurance Company's gone. Ah, Claus, those premiums! Now, our lives Depend on yours: thus griefs go on. ââAnd even while you're thus harassed, I do believe, if out you went, You'd go, in spite of all that's passed, To the children of that President!â âOh, Charley, Harry, Nimblewits, These eyes, that night, ne'er slept a wink. My path seemed honeycombed with pits. Naught could I do but think and think. âBut, with the day, my courage rose. Ne'er shall my boys, my boys (I cried), When Christmas morns their eyes unclose, Find empty stockings gaping wide! âThen hewed and whacked and whittled I; The wife, the girls and Kris took fire; They spun, sewed, cut,âtill by and by We made, at home, my pack entire!â (He handed me a bundle, here.) âNow, hoist me up: there, gently: quick! Dear boys, don't look for much this year: Remember, Santa Claus is sick!â Baltimore, December, 1877.

Down mildest shores of milk-white sand, By cape and fair Floridian bay, Twixt billowy pinesâa surf asleep on landâ And the great Gulf at play, Past far-off palms that filmed to nought, Or in and out the cunning keys That laced the land like fragile patterns wrought To edge old broideries. The sail sighed on all day for joy, The prow each pouting wave did leave All smile and song, with sheen and ripple coy, Till the dusk diver Eve Brought up from out the brimming East The oval moon, a perfect pearl. WEDDING-HYMN. Thou God, whose high, eternal Love Is the only blue sky of our life, Clear all the Heaven that bends above The life-road of this man and wife. Macon, Georgia, 1867. NIGHT. Fair is the wedded reign of Night and Day. Each rules a half of earth with different sway, Exchanging kingdoms, East and West, alway. Like the round pearl that Egypt drunk in wine, The sun half sinks i' the brimming, rosy brine: The wild Night drinks all up: how her eyes shine! Now the swift sail of straining life is furled, And through the stillness of my soul is whirled The throbbing of the hearts of half the world. I hear the cries that follow Birth and Death. I hear huge Pestilence draw his vaporous breath: âBeware, prepare, or else ye die,â he saith. I hear a haggard student turn and sigh: I hear men begging Heaven to let them die: And, drowning all, a wild-eyed woman's cry. So Night takes toll of Wisdom as of Sin. The student's and the drunkard's cheek is thin: But flesh is not the prize we strive to win. Now airy swarms of fluttering dreams descend On souls, like birds on trees, and have no end. O God, from vulture-dreams my soul defend! Let fall on Her a rose-leaf rain of dreams, All passionate-sweet, as are the loving beams Of starlight on the glimmering woods and streams.
